ज्ञ - The jiva is the knower (jnata) and possesses real consciousness
Is the jiva truly conscious, or is consciousness merely a property of matter (as materialists claim) or reflection of Brahman's consciousness (as some Vedantins say)?
Consciousness is either produced by material combination (Charvaka), or is borrowed/reflected from Brahman (some Advaita interpretations).

According to Dvaita: Jiva possesses real, intrinsic consciousness (jnana-svarupa). Madhva establishes: (1) Consciousness is the essential nature (svarupa) of jiva, not a produced quality, (2) Each jiva's consciousness is real and eternal, not illusory or borrowed, (3) However, jiva's knowledge is limited and dependent on Vishnu's grace, unlike Vishnu's infinite omniscience, (4) The jiva knows through its consciousness but is also subject to ignorance and error due to its limitations. While Vishnu is self-luminous (svaprakasha) and illumines all, jivas have derivative consciousness (paraprakasha)—real but dependent. The jiva is truly the knower, experiencer, and agent, but all these functions depend on Vishnu's enabling presence as antaryamin.

Dvaita realism about consciousness: Madhva rejects both materialism (consciousness from matter) and illusionism (consciousness as false). Jiva's consciousness is real but limited and dependent on Vishnu.
Katha Upanishad 2.2.15, Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 4.3.7, Bhagavad Gita 13.2
उत्क्रान्ति - The jiva's departure from the body at death and its journey thereafter
What happens to the jiva at death? Does it cease to exist, merge with Brahman, or continue as a distinct entity?
At death, the jiva either perishes (materialism), or merges into Brahman temporarily or permanently (various Vedantic views).

According to Dvaita: At death, the jiva departs the body as a distinct entity and continues its journey. Madhva's teaching: (1) The jiva leaves through specific nadis (channels) based on its karma and spiritual state, (2) The jiva carries subtle impressions (samskaras) and karmic traces, (3) For bound souls: the jiva goes to heaven/hell for temporary enjoyment/suffering based on karma, then returns to earth for rebirth, (4) For liberated souls: the jiva travels via the path of light (devayana) to Vishnu's abode (Vaikuntha), never to return to samsara, (5) In all cases, the jiva maintains its individual identity—it never merges or dissolves. Even in moksha, the jiva exists eternally as a distinct, blissful devotee of Vishnu. The journey after death is real, not illusory.

Dvaita eschatology: Jiva's individuality is eternal. No merging occurs at death or liberation. This establishes continuing personal relationship with Vishnu in moksha, distinguishing Madhva sharply from Advaita.
Chandogya Upanishad 5.10, Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 4.4.1-7, Bhagavad Gita 8.5-6, 8.23-26
व्यतिरेक - The jiva exists independently of the elements and persists when they dissolve
Is the jiva produced from and dependent on material elements, or does it exist independently?
Materialist view: Consciousness arises from elements like wine from grapes. When elements dissolve, consciousness ceases.

According to Dvaita: The jiva is entirely independent of (vyatirikta) material elements. Madhva refutes materialism: (1) Jiva is conscious by nature, elements are inert—consciousness cannot arise from non-consciousness, (2) Jiva pre-exists the body and survives its dissolution, (3) Memory of past lives (seen in rare cases) proves jiva's continuity beyond one body, (4) Shruti repeatedly affirms atman's eternality: 'never born, never dies' (Gita 2.20). Elements combine to form the body as jiva's instrument, but jiva itself is not produced by elements. When elements dissolve at death, jiva continues. This establishes jiva as a distinct ontological category beyond matter.

Dvaita anti-materialism: Madhva firmly establishes jiva's non-material nature. Consciousness is fundamental, not epiphenomenal. Jiva belongs to the conscious (chetana) category, elements to inert (jada).
Katha Upanishad 1.2.18, Bhagavad Gita 2.20-25
पृथक्उपदेश - Separate instruction about jiva and Brahman in Upanishads proves their eternal distinction
Why do Upanishads give separate instructions about jiva and Brahman if they are identical?
Advaita: Separate instruction is due to ignorance. Ultimately jiva and Brahman are one.

According to Dvaita: Separate instruction proves eternal distinction (bheda). Madhva's argument: (1) Upanishads consistently describe jiva and Paramatman as two distinct entities (e.g., two birds in Mundaka), (2) Instructions like 'know the atman' and 'know Brahman' are given separately, indicating different objects of knowledge, (3) If jiva were identical with Brahman, instructing jiva to know Brahman would be meaningless, (4) The very possibility of ignorance in jiva proves distinction—Brahman cannot be ignorant. Separate scriptural treatment (prithag-upadesha) establishes separate reality. Jiva is always dependent knower, Vishnu is always independent omniscient controller. This eternal distinction is real (vastu-bheda), not merely conventional.
Dvaita exegesis: Madhva uses scriptural structure itself as proof of duality. The persistent two-fold teaching in Upanishads isn't pedagogical convenience but reflects metaphysical reality.
Mundaka Upanishad 3.1.1, Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 3.7, Shvetashvatara Upanishad 1.6
यावत् - The jiva's embodied existence continues until liberation (moksha)
Does the jiva achieve liberation while still embodied, or only after final death?
Advaita: Jnana immediately liberates; the body may continue but bondage ceases instantly (jivanmukti).

According to Dvaita: Complete liberation occurs only after the body falls (videhamukti). Madhva's position: (1) As long as the body exists, some connection with prakriti remains, hence complete freedom is impossible, (2) True moksha means reaching Vaikuntha and experiencing direct vision of Vishnu—this happens only after death, (3) While living, the devotee may have profound realization and freedom from fear, but full liberation awaits, (4) The jiva continues in embodied state 'until' (yavat) the prarabdha karma exhausts. Madhva does not accept jivanmukti in the Advaita sense. The highest living state is para-bhakti (supreme devotion), which culminates in videha-mukti after death. Then the jiva reaches Vaikuntha for eternal blissful service to Vishnu.

Dvaita eschatology: No merging, no immediate liberation. The jiva's journey completes in Vaikuntha with eternal individual existence in Vishnu's presence. Moksha is reaching Vishnu, not becoming Vishnu.
Chandogya Upanishad 6.14.2, Bhagavad Gita 4.9, 8.5
पुंस्त्व - The jiva is atomic in size (anu-parimana) yet pervades the body through consciousness
What is the size of the jiva? Is it all-pervading like Brahman, or limited?
Jiva is all-pervading (vibhu) like Brahman, or is the size of the body.

According to Dvaita: The jiva is atomic in size (anu). Madhva's reasoning: (1) If jiva were all-pervading, it would experience all bodies simultaneously—but each jiva experiences only one body, (2) If jiva were body-sized, it couldn't transmigrate to different-sized bodies, (3) Jiva is anu (atomic), residing in the heart region, but its consciousness (jnana-guna) pervades the entire body, (4) This explains how we feel sensations throughout the body though the jiva itself is located in one place. The atomic jiva differs from all-pervading Vishnu. Vishnu is vibhu (all-pervading), jivas are anu (atomic). This distinction is eternal and real. The jiva's atomic nature proves it is limited and dependent, never capable of independent omnipresence like Vishnu.

Dvaita unique doctrine: Atomic jiva is distinctive Madhva teaching. It reconciles jiva's limitedness with its body-wide experience through the distinction between jiva's svarupa (atomic) and its guna (consciousness quality that pervades).
Mundaka Upanishad 3.1.9, Shvetashvatara Upanishad 5.8-9
कर्तृत्व - The jiva is a real agent (karta) of actions, though dependent on Vishnu's permission
Is the jiva truly the agent of its actions, or is Brahman the sole agent? Does agency create bondage?
Either: (1) Brahman alone acts, jiva is passive (some Vedantic views), or (2) Jiva acts independently without divine involvement (Sankhya-Yoga view).

According to Dvaita: Jiva is a real but dependent agent. Madhva's nuanced position: (1) Jiva is the karta (agent)—it genuinely performs actions and experiences results, (2) However, jiva's agency is not independent—every action requires Vishnu's sanction and enabling power, (3) Vishnu, as antaryamin, permits actions aligned with jiva's karma and nature but is not the doer of individual jiva's actions, (4) Good actions arise when jiva aligns with Vishnu's will; evil actions when jiva misuses its limited freedom, (5) Jiva bears moral responsibility for its actions—karma-phala (results) accrue to the jiva, not to Vishnu. This establishes limited agency: jiva is subordinate karta (asvatantra-karta), Vishnu is supreme controller (niyanta). Vishnu enables but doesn't compel; jiva chooses but cannot act without divine permission. This solves the free will problem while maintaining Vishnu's sovereignty.

Dvaita theodicy and free will: Madhva's doctrine of limited agency is sophisticated. It avoids both fatalism (jiva has no freedom) and absolute free will (jiva is independent). Jiva has real but constrained agency under Vishnu's governance.
Bhagavad Gita 3.27, 5.14, 15.15, 18.61, Katha Upanishad 2.2.13
अंश - The jiva is not a 'part' (amsha) of Brahman but an eternally distinct entity dependent on Brahman
When Shruti says jiva is an 'amsha' (part) of Brahman, does this mean jiva is identical with Brahman, or a real fragment, or something else?
Jiva is either: (1) A real part/fragment of Brahman (implying Brahman is divisible), or (2) Identical with Brahman (Advaita), or (3) Reflects Brahman like sparks from fire.

According to Dvaita: 'Amsha' means eternally dependent entity, not literal part. Madhva's interpretation: (1) Brahman (Vishnu) is indivisible (akhanda)—calling jiva a 'part' doesn't mean Vishnu is fragmented, (2) 'Amsha' metaphorically indicates jiva's eternal dependence on and subordination to Vishnu, just as parts depend on the whole, (3) Jiva and Vishnu are eternally distinct (bheda), never identical or fragments separated from unity, (4) The relationship is controller-controlled (niyamya-niyamaka), body-soul (sharira-shariri), not whole-part in material sense. Vishnu remains complete and unaffected; jivas exist as eternally dependent conscious beings. This refutes both identity (Advaita) and real partition theories. Madhva's unique position: jivas are real, distinct, eternal, and utterly dependent—not illusions, not parts, not identical.

Dvaita subtle metaphysics: This adhikarana shows Madhva's careful exegesis. He maintains Vishnu's absolute unity while affirming jiva's reality and distinction. The amsha doctrine is crucial for Dvaita theology.
Bhagavad Gita 15.7 ('mamaivamsho jiva-loke'), Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 2.5.19
अदृष्ट - Karma (unseen moral force/adrishta) governs jiva's experiences under Vishnu's supervision
What determines the jiva's experiences of pleasure and pain? Is it arbitrary divine will, karma, or both?
Either karma operates independently without God (Mimamsa-Sankhya view), or God arbitrarily dispenses results without regard to karma (some theistic views).

According to Dvaita: Karma operates under Vishnu's governance. Madhva's synthesis: (1) Karma (adrishta/apurva) is real—actions create invisible impressions that determine future experiences, (2) However, karma is not independent or self-executing—Vishnu as antaryamin supervises and administers karmic results, (3) Vishnu ensures perfect justice: each jiva receives exactly what its karma warrants, neither more nor less, (4) Vishnu is not arbitrary or partial—He follows the law of karma but He established that law and maintains it. This resolves the problem: karma explains diversity and suffering (avoiding accusations of divine arbitrariness), while Vishnu's supervision ensures cosmic order and possibility of grace. Madhva's position avoids both mechanical fatalism and divine caprice. This concludes Chapter 2 Pada 3.

Dvaita theodicy completion: Karma + Vishnu's supervision = perfect justice system. Neither pure determinism (karma alone) nor pure voluntarism (God's whim alone), but harmonious integration. This completes the entire discussion of creation, jiva nature, and cosmic governance.
Bhagavad Gita 9.29, Brahma Sutra 2.3.41, Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 3.2.13
प्राण - Whether Prana (vital force) is a created entity or is it Brahman itself, and its origin
Is Prana mentioned in Upanishads an independent uncreated principle, a created entity, or Brahman itself? If created, from where does it originate?
Prana is either Brahman itself (since it's called greatest), or it's an uncreated independent principle like air, or it's the jiva since it experiences.

According to Dvaita: Prana (mukhya prana, chief vital force) is a created entity, distinct from both Brahman and jiva. It originates from Vishnu during creation. Madhva establishes: (1) Prana is a real substance (dravya), not mere function - it has specific qualities and performs distinct activities, (2) Prana is created by Vishnu from Himself, making it part of the dependent reality, (3) Prana is insentient (jada) but animated by Vishnu's antaryamin presence, (4) The five vital airs (prana, apana, vyana, udana, samana) are modifications of mukhya prana, (5) Prana is different from jiva - jiva is conscious and eternal, prana is unconscious and created, (6) Prana pervades the body and enables all physiological functions under jiva's directive and Vishnu's ultimate control. The statement 'prana is born from Atman' (Prashnopanishad 3.3) confirms its origin from Vishnu. Prana is Vishnu's shakti manifested as vital energy.

Dvaita: Madhva's realistic ontology includes prana as a distinct created principle. Unlike Advaita (which reduces prana to Brahman or maya), Madhva affirms prana's reality as Vishnu's creation. This establishes the complexity of creation - conscious Vishnu, conscious jivas, and various unconscious principles including prana all working in harmony under Vishnu's control.
Prashnopanishad 3.3, Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 1.3.19-22, Chandogya Upanishad 5.1
मनः - Whether the mind (manas) is a sense organ (indriya) or distinct from the sense organs
Is the mind merely another sense organ like the ten indriyas, or is it a distinct principle? Should it be counted among the indriyas or separately?
Mind is just the eleventh sense organ, functioning like others to perceive its objects (internal thoughts).

According to Dvaita: Mind (manas) is distinct from the ten sense organs (five knowledge organs and five action organs) though it shares some characteristics with them. Madhva's position: (1) Mind is ubhayatmaka - it has dual nature, functioning both as knowledge organ and action organ, (2) Mind is the internal organ (antah-karana) coordinating all sense perceptions - no sense can function without mind's attention, (3) Mind is atomic (anu) in size, like the jiva, enabling its singular focus at any moment, (4) Mind is created from sattvic aspect of elements during cosmic creation, (5) Mind is the instrument (karana) through which jiva cognizes and wills, but jiva is the ultimate knower, not the mind, (6) Mind is insentient (jada) - consciousness belongs to jiva alone; mind merely reflects jiva's consciousness like a mirror. Unlike senses which perceive only external objects, mind perceives both external (coordinated through senses) and internal (thoughts, memories, imagination). All mental activities occur under Vishnu's antaryamin control.

Dvaita clarity: Madhva maintains clear distinction between conscious jiva and unconscious mind. This refutes Buddhist vijnanavada (consciousness-only) and establishes that mind is a real but inert instrument. The jiva uses mind as its primary instrument for experiencing the world.
Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 1.5.3, Chandogya Upanishad 7.3.1, Katha Upanishad 1.3.3-4
वाक् - Speech (vak) and other action organs are created from elements and are distinct principles
Are speech and other action organs (karmendriyas) merely functions of prana, or are they distinct created entities? What is their origin?
Speech is just a function of the vital air (prana), not a separate organ. Similarly, other action organs are merely prana in different modes.

According to Dvaita: Speech (vak) and the five action organs (karmendriyas - speech, hands, feet, organs of excretion and generation) are distinct created entities, not mere functions of prana. Madhva's teaching: (1) Each action organ has its own specific power (shakti) derived from particular deities - Agni presides over speech, Indra over hands, Vishnu over feet, Yama over excretion, Prajapati over generation, (2) The action organs originate from the rajasic aspect of the five elements during creation, (3) Each organ is a real distinct principle (tattva), though all function in coordination under mind's direction, (4) The organs cannot function without prana's support, but they are not identical to prana - prana energizes, organs execute specific actions, (5) All organs ultimately function under the control of Vishnu as antaryamin - through presiding deities, Vishnu exercises control over each organ's function. The scripture 'From Him (Brahman) speech and prana arise' (Mundaka 2.1.3) confirms their creation from Vishnu. Though distinct, all physiological instruments work in perfect harmony as parts of Vishnu's controlled creation.

Dvaita realism: Madhva's detailed ontology recognizes multiple real entities coordinating in bodily function. This opposes reductionism (reducing everything to one principle) and establishes the complex orchestration of Vishnu's creation where multiple dependent principles work in hierarchy.
Mundaka Upanishad 2.1.3, Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 1.3.2-7, Prashnopanishad 2.3
सप्तगति - The seven gates/apertures mentioned in scripture and the enumeration of sense organs
What are the 'seven gates' of the city (body) mentioned in Upanishads? How many sense organs are there - seven, eleven, or another number?
There are only seven organs corresponding to the seven openings in the head (two eyes, two ears, two nostrils, one mouth).

According to Dvaita: The 'seven gates' refer specifically to the seven openings in the head through which knowledge is acquired, but the total number of organs is not limited to seven. Madhva's clarification: (1) The seven gates (sapta dwara) are the seven apertures in the head region - two eyes, two ears, two nostrils, and one mouth, (2) These seven are specifically mentioned because they are primary channels for external knowledge acquisition, (3) However, the complete enumeration includes: eleven organs total - five knowledge organs (jnanendriyas: eye, ear, nose, tongue, skin), five action organs (karmendriyas: speech, hands, feet, excretion, generation), plus mind as the coordinating internal organ, (4) Different scriptural passages emphasize different enumerations based on teaching context - seven when emphasizing knowledge gates, ten when discussing organs alone, eleven including mind, (5) All these organs are Vishnu's creation, instruments for jiva's embodied experience. The Mundaka passage 'two eyes, two ears...' and Chandogya's enumeration are reconciled by understanding contextual emphasis. All organs, regardless of number, function under Vishnu's antaryamin governance.

Dvaita: Madhva reconciles apparent contradictions in scriptural numbers through contextual interpretation. This demonstrates sophisticated hermeneutics - scripture's varying enumerations reflect pedagogical emphasis, not contradiction.
Mundaka Upanishad 2.1.8, Chandogya Upanishad 3.13.8, Prashnopanishad 4.2
अणुत्व - Whether the sense organs are atomic (anu) in size or all-pervading
Are the sense organs atomic in dimension or are they all-pervading throughout the body? What is their actual size/extent?
The organs must be all-pervading since they function throughout the body - skin feels everywhere, etc.

According to Dvaita: The internal organ (mind) and the sense organs are atomic (anu-parimana) in essential nature, though their effects extend throughout the body. Madhva's position: (1) Each organ's essential substance (svarupa) is atomic - concentrated at specific locations in the body, (2) The apparent all-pervasiveness is functional, not substantial - skin sensitivity throughout doesn't mean the organ itself is all-pervading, but that its power extends via nerve connections, (3) Mind is specifically atomic, enabling focused attention - if mind were all-pervading, simultaneous awareness of everything would occur, contradicting experience of sequential attention, (4) The organs' atomic nature parallels jiva's atomic nature - both reside at specific locations (heart) but their consciousness/function extends throughout the body, (5) This atomic nature doesn't limit their efficiency - under Vishnu's design, atomic organs perfectly serve their purposes through their extended functional presence. Scriptural statements like 'the atomic organ' and the fact that organs can be individually impaired at specific locations support this view. The atomic instruments serve jiva's embodied experience under Vishnu's perfect orchestration.

Dvaita distinctive: Madhva's atomic theory of organs parallels his atomic theory of jiva. This realism distinguishes him from Advaita (all-pervading consciousness) and establishes precise metaphysics of embodied existence.
Chandogya Upanishad 8.12.4, Katha Upanishad 1.3.4, Mundaka Upanishad 3.1.9
मुख्यप्राण - The chief prana (mukhya prana) is distinct from and superior to the sense organs
Is the chief prana (mukhya prana) the same as the sense organs or distinct from them? What is its status and function?
Mukhya prana is just another name for the aggregate of sense organs, or it's identical to the breathing function.

According to Dvaita: Mukhya prana (the chief vital force) is a distinct principle, superior to and independent of the sense organs. Madhva's teaching: (1) Mukhya prana is the primary life-sustaining energy in the body, distinct from the five subsidiary pranas (prana, apana, vyana, udana, samana), (2) The sense organs depend on prana for their functioning - when prana leaves, all organs cease operation, but prana exists independently of organs, (3) In the famous dialogue where organs compete for supremacy (Brihadaranyaka 6.1, Chandogya 5.1), prana is declared greatest because life continues without individual organs but not without prana, (4) Mukhya prana is Vishnu's direct energy maintaining embodied existence - it's the link between jiva and body, enabling the atomic jiva to animate the entire physical form, (5) The five subsidiary vital airs are functional modifications of mukhya prana, each serving specific physiological roles, (6) Prana operates under Vishnu's constant control as antaryamin - it is insentient shakti directed by conscious Vishnu. The Upanishadic teaching 'Prana alone does not leave the dying person' (when it does leave, death occurs) establishes its primacy. Mukhya prana is Vishnu's sustaining power individualized in each body.

Dvaita: Madhva's hierarchy places mukhya prana above organs but below jiva and Vishnu. This establishes gradation even among insentient principles - some jada entities (like prana) are more fundamental than others (like organs).
Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 6.1.7-14, Chandogya Upanishad 5.1.1-15, Prashnopanishad 2.3
चक्षुरादि - The eyes and other sense organs originate from elements, not directly from Brahman
Do the sense organs originate directly from Brahman, or do they arise from the elements? What is the sequence of their creation?
Since all creation originates from Brahman, the organs too come directly from Brahman without intermediate stages.

According to Dvaita: The sense organs originate from the elements (bhutas), not directly from Vishnu/Brahman. The creation sequence follows hierarchy. Madhva's teaching: (1) Vishnu first creates the five elements (panchamahabhuta - akasha, vayu, agni, ap, prithvi), (2) From these elements, the subtle organs are formed - each organ derives from specific element(s): eyes from tejas (fire/light), ears from akasha, nose from prithvi (earth), tongue from ap (water), skin from vayu (air), (3) This is mediated creation - Vishnu creates elements, elements produce organs, establishing layered causation, (4) The presiding deities (Surya for eyes, Dik for ears, Ashvins for nose, Varuna for tongue, Vayu for skin) are appointed by Vishnu to govern respective organs, (5) Though ultimately traceable to Vishnu as the supreme cause, the immediate material cause of organs is elemental - this establishes real transformation (parinama) in creation, (6) Mind originates from the sattvic essence of all elements combined. This mediated creation demonstrates Vishnu's systematic methodology - not arbitrary instant creation but orderly sequential manifestation. Each level of reality arises from the previous under Vishnu's governance, maintaining the organic unity of creation.

Dvaita realism: Madhva's parinama-vada (real transformation) establishes genuine causation chains. Unlike Advaita's vivarta (apparent causation), Madhva affirms real sequential causation under Vishnu's ultimate control - both intermediate causes and supreme cause are real.
Taittiriya Upanishad 2.1, Chandogya Upanishad 6.5.4, Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 1.3
पञ्चवृत्ति - The five-fold function or division of prana into five vital airs
Are the five pranas (prana, apana, vyana, udana, samana) five distinct entities or one prana with five functions? How to understand their plurality?
The five pranas are completely distinct entities, each created separately and functioning independently.

According to Dvaita: The five vital airs are functional modifications or aspects of the one mukhya prana, not entirely separate entities. Madhva's position: (1) There is one essential prana (mukhya prana) which manifests in five functional modes based on location and activity, (2) The five-fold division: Prana (upward-moving breath, seated in heart/chest), Apana (downward-moving, in lower abdomen), Vyana (pervading throughout body), Udana (ascending, in throat enabling speech), Samana (centered in navel region, aids digestion), (3) These are not five independent substances but one prana performing five distinct physiological functions through different locations and movements in the body, (4) All five depend on mukhya prana - when the chief prana departs at death, all five cease simultaneously, (5) The functional plurality serves the jiva's embodied experience - different bodily activities require differentiated vital support, (6) Under Vishnu's governance as antaryamin, the one prana diversifies its operation for perfect bodily function. The analogy: like one gold shaped into five ornaments, or one actor playing five roles. The scriptural enumeration of five pranas indicates functional distinction within essential unity. This establishes both unity (one prana) and diversity (five functions) in the vital energy system.

Dvaita: Madhva's 'functional plurality within essential unity' applies here - one reality with multiple operations. This is distinct from absolute monism (denying plurality) and absolute pluralism (denying unity). Madhva's middle path affirms both.
Prashnopanishad 3.5-7, Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 1.5.3, Taittiriya Upanishad 1.7
प्राणाणुत्व - Whether prana is atomic or all-pervading in dimension
Is prana atomic (anu) in size or all-pervading (vibhu) throughout the body? What is its actual spatial extent?
Prana must be all-pervading since its effects are felt throughout the body from head to toe.

According to Dvaita: Prana is atomic (anu-parimana) in its essential nature, though its functional effects pervade the entire body. Madhva's teaching: (1) Mukhya prana in its essential substance is atomic, concentrated in the heart region where it resides with the jiva, (2) Though atomic in substance, prana's activity extends throughout the body via the five functional modifications (prana, apana, etc.) operating in different regions, (3) The all-pervading effect doesn't require all-pervading substance - like fire in one place illuminating an entire room, atomic prana from the heart vitalizes the whole body, (4) Prana's atomic nature enables its coordinated functioning - if all-pervading, it couldn't have distinct functional divisions in different bodily regions, (5) Scripture supports atomic nature: prana is born from Atman, resides in the heart, and departs at death - all indicating localized essential presence, (6) The atomic prana operates under Vishnu's antaryamin control, its power extended through divine design to serve embodied existence perfectly. The body's vitalization by atomic prana demonstrates Vishnu's ingenious creation - minimal substance with maximal function through intelligent design. Both jiva and mukhya prana are atomic, working in tandem in the heart to animate the body.

Dvaita consistency: Madhva maintains parallel atomic theories for jiva, manas, and prana - all essential instruments of embodied existence are atomic in nature. This coherent framework distinguishes Dvaita's precise metaphysics.
Prashnopanishad 3.3, Mundaka Upanishad 2.1.3, Katha Upanishad 2.1.13
ज्योतिः - The light/effulgence from which organs arise refers to Brahman, not physical light
When scripture says organs arise from 'light' (jyoti), does this refer to physical light/fire element or to Brahman as the source?
The 'light' is the physical element tejas (fire), from which organs materially originate.

According to Dvaita: The 'light' (jyoti) mentioned as the ultimate source of organs is Vishnu/Brahman, not merely the physical element. Madhva's clarification: (1) While organs immediately originate from elements (as established in adhikarana 89), the ultimate source is Vishnu - the chain is: Vishnu → elements → organs, (2) Scripture uses 'light' (jyoti) as a metaphor for Vishnu's luminous consciousness and creative power - He is the self-effulgent reality (svaprakasha), (3) The creation sequence in Chandogya shows Brahman as the initial cause even of elements: 'From Sat (Brahman) arose tejas, from tejas arose water...', (4) Vishnu is called 'jyoti' because all illumination, consciousness, and manifestation derive from Him - He is both the light of consciousness and the power behind physical light, (5) The presiding deities of organs (Surya for eyes, etc.) derive their power from Vishnu as the supreme controller, (6) Thus organs have a dual origin: proximate material cause (elements) and ultimate efficient cause (Vishnu). Understanding both levels prevents confusion - Dvaita realism acknowledges intermediate causes without denying the supreme cause. Everything ultimately traces to Vishnu as the fountain of all existence, but through real sequential manifestation.

Dvaita synthesis: Madhva harmonizes immediate causation (elements) with ultimate causation (Vishnu). This avoids both reductionism (denying intermediate causes) and fragmentation (denying unity of ultimate source). Real multilevel causation under one supreme cause.
Chandogya Upanishad 6.2-4, Mundaka Upanishad 2.1.1, Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 4.4.16
इन्द्रिय - The organs have presiding deities (abhimani devatas) governing their functions
Do the sense organs function autonomously, or are they governed by presiding deities? What is the role of these deities?
The organs function mechanically based on physical causation, without need for presiding deities. Or the deities are merely poetic personifications.

According to Dvaita: Each organ has a real presiding deity (abhimani devata) who governs and empowers its function under Vishnu's supreme authority. Madhva's doctrine: (1) The presiding deities are real conscious beings (jivas of superior status), not mere symbols - they include: Surya (Sun) for eyes, Dik-devatas (Directions) for ears, Ashvini Kumaras for nose, Varuna for tongue, Vayu for skin/touch, Agni for speech, Indra for hands, Vishnu for feet, Mitra for excretion, Prajapati for generation, Chandra (Moon) for mind, (2) These deities empower the organs to function - an organ without its presiding deity's presence cannot operate properly, (3) The relationship is hierarchical: Vishnu (supreme controller) → presiding deities (intermediate controllers) → organs (instruments) → jiva (experiencer). All levels are real and necessary, (4) The deities themselves are controlled by Vishnu as antaryamin - they exercise delegated authority, not independent power, (5) This establishes taratamya (hierarchical gradation) even in physiological functioning - multiple levels of conscious control, (6) When organs are praised in Upanishads, the praise ultimately goes to Vishnu through the deities. Understanding presiding deities prevents both materialism (denying conscious governance) and pantheism (identifying organs with ultimate deity). Dvaita's multilayered reality: inert organs, conscious deities, supreme Vishnu - all real, all coordinated.

Dvaita distinctive: Madhva's realistic acceptance of Vedic deities as real conscious beings governing cosmic/physiological functions sets Dvaita apart. This isn't primitive animism but sophisticated hierarchical theism - multiple real conscious agents under one supreme will.
Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 3.9.10-17, Prashnopanishad 2.3-4, Aitareya Aranyaka 2.4
संज्ञा - The designations/names used for organs in Upanishads and their proper interpretation
When Upanishads use various names for organs (like calling speech 'Agni', eyes 'Surya'), do these refer to the organs themselves or to the presiding deities?
These names refer only to the presiding deities, not to the physical organs.

According to Dvaita: The names can refer to both the organs and their presiding deities depending on context, because of their intimate connection. Madhva's hermeneutic principle: (1) When scripture says 'Agni is speech,' it indicates the intimate relationship between Agni (presiding deity) and the speech organ - the deity empowers and controls the organ, (2) The naming is based on functional identity - the organ functions through the deity's power, so they can be referred to interchangeably in functional contexts, (3) However, essential distinction remains - the deity is conscious (chit), the organ is inert (jada); the deity is eternal (nitya), the organ is created (karya), (4) Context determines whether the reference is primarily to organ or deity: in ritual contexts often the deity, in physiological contexts the organ, in philosophical contexts both layers, (5) This dual reference doesn't create confusion but reveals Vedantic depth - every physical reality has conscious governance behind it, (6) Understanding this principle prevents crude materialism (seeing only organs) and abstract spiritualism (denying organs' reality). Madhva's interpretation maintains both levels: physical organs are real, presiding deities are real, their connection is real. Scripture's flexible terminology reflects this multilayered reality. Names reveal relationships, not just isolated entities.

Dvaita hermeneutics: Madhva's contextual interpretation allows scripture's varied terminology without contradiction. This sophisticated reading sees Upanishadic language as revealing complex reality, not simple one-to-one correspondence. Both levels of reality are honored.
Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 1.3.2-8, Chandogya Upanishad 5.1, Prashnopanishad 2.3
मांस - The subtle elements (sukshma bhutas) and their relationship to organs; the body's subtle and gross aspects
Are the subtle elements distinct from gross elements? Do organs arise from subtle or gross elements? What constitutes the subtle body?
There are only gross elements; subtle elements are just the gross elements in finer form, not distinct entities.

According to Dvaita: Subtle elements (sukshma bhutas or tanmatras) are distinct from gross elements and serve as the material cause for organs and subtle body. Madhva's teaching: (1) Each gross element has a corresponding subtle form: subtle akasha (shabda-tanmatra), subtle vayu (sparsha-tanmatra), subtle tejas (rupa-tanmatra), subtle ap (rasa-tanmatra), subtle prithvi (gandha-tanmatra), (2) Organs arise primarily from these subtle elements - eyes from subtle tejas, ears from subtle akasha, etc. The gross elements form the gross body (sthula sharira), while subtle elements form organs and subtle body (sukshma sharira), (3) The subtle body consists of: mind, intellect (buddhi), ego (ahamkara), the sense organs, vital airs, and subtle elements - this persists through death and rebirth, carrying the jiva's karma, (4) At death, the gross body dissolves into gross elements, but the subtle body remains with jiva until liberation, (5) This establishes three levels: gross body (annamaya), subtle body (pranamaya, manomaya, vijnanamaya), and causal connection to Vishnu (anandamaya), (6) All levels - gross, subtle, and causal - are real (not illusory), created by Vishnu, and controlled by Him as antaryamin. The subtle body is the transmigrating entity, vehicle of karmic continuity across births. Understanding this resolves the paradox: jiva is eternal and unchanging in essence, yet experiences varied embodiments - the subtle body changes while jiva's essential nature persists. This concludes Chapter 2 Pada 4 on the microcosm - organs, pranas, and embodied existence.

Dvaita doctrine: Madhva's acceptance of both gross and subtle bodies as real establishes the framework for reincarnation and karma. Unlike Advaita (subtle body is maya), Madhva affirms its reality, explaining empirical transmigration while maintaining jiva's essential eternality. The subtle body is the link between unchanging jiva and changing embodiments.
Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 4.4.1-7, Prashnopanishad 4.8-9, Taittiriya Upanishad 2.1-5
तदन्तर - The intermediate state (antarala) between death and the next birth or liberation
What happens to the jiva in the period between death of the current body and attainment of the next birth or liberation? Is there an intermediate state?
The jiva immediately enters a new body at death, or it remains unconscious until rebirth. There is no conscious intermediate state.

According to Dvaita: There is an intermediate state after death before the next embodiment or liberation. Madhva's teaching: (1) The jiva, clothed in the subtle body (sukshma sharira), departs from the gross body at death while retaining full consciousness and individual identity, (2) This intermediate existence is conscious - the jiva experiences the results of karma through the subtle body, traveling to various realms (svarga/naraka) or proceeding to Vaikuntha if liberated, (3) The duration varies based on karma - some jivas quickly enter new bodies, others spend extended periods in heavenly/hellish realms before rebirth, (4) During this state, the jiva maintains its eternal distinction from Vishnu and from other jivas - no merging or loss of individuality occurs, (5) Vishnu as antaryamin accompanies the jiva throughout this journey, witnessing and controlling but not experiencing the jiva's karma-phala, (6) For liberated souls (muktas), this intermediate period is the journey to Vaikuntha via the devayana path. This establishes continuity of personal identity across births and affirms conscious post-mortem existence. The subtle body is the vehicle of transmigration, carrying karmic impressions (samskaras) until liberation.

Dvaita: This begins Chapter 3 on sadhana (spiritual practice) and phala (results). Madhva's doctrine of conscious intermediate existence opposes theories of unconscious gaps. The jiva's eternal individuality and consciousness are maintained throughout death, intermediate state, and rebirth.
Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 4.4.1-7, Chandogya Upanishad 5.10, Katha Upanishad 1.2.6
त्र्यात्मकत्व - The three-fold nature of the jiva at death (consciousness, subtle body, and accompanying elements)
What exactly constitutes the departing entity at death? Does only pure consciousness leave, or does something material accompany it?
Only the pure jiva (consciousness) departs; all material aspects including subtle body are left behind.

According to Dvaita: The departing entity has three aspects. Madhva's analysis: (1) The jiva itself - eternal atomic conscious entity, unchanging in essence, (2) The subtle body - mind, intellect, ego, sense organs, vital airs, subtle elements; carrier of karmic impressions, (3) Subtle elemental particles - traces of five elements forming support for subtle body during transmigration. Scripture confirms: 'surrounded by subtle parts of elements, he departs.' Three-fold departure ensures continuity of personality (jiva), continuity of karma (subtle body), and basis for future embodiment (elemental seeds). This explains how jiva maintains unique characteristics across births—memory traces, inherent qualities, accumulated karma all travel with subtle body. Vishnu as antaryamin pervades all three aspects, controlling entire transmigration process.

Dvaita realism: Madhva's three-fold analysis maintains both jiva's essential immutability and experiential continuity. Subtle body is real, not illusory, enabling genuine transmigration with karmic continuity.
Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 4.4.2-3, Prashnopanishad 3.10, Chandogya Upanishad 6.8.6
प्राणागति - Whether prana (vital force) departs with jiva at death or dissolves into elements
When jiva departs at death, does mukhya prana (chief vital force) go with it, or does prana merge into cosmic elements?
Prana, being material, dissolves back into cosmic prana or elements at death. Only jiva with mind departs.

According to Dvaita: Mukhya prana departs with jiva as part of subtle body. Madhva: (1) Prana is integral component of subtle body—inseparable from jiva's embodied existence even in subtle form, (2) Vital force that leaves is subtle prana animating subtle body, not gross breathing, (3) Scripture: 'when he departs, prana follows; when prana departs, all vital airs follow'—indicating prana's inseparability from departing jiva, (4) Five vital airs in subtle form accompany jiva, enabling subtle body's functioning during transmigration, (5) Only gross physical aspects of prana dissolve into elements. Jiva retains vitality in subtle embodiment—subtle body animated by subtle prana. When new gross body assumed, subtle prana manifests as gross vital functions again.
Dvaita: Subtle prana's continuity explains why transmigrating jiva maintains life-like characteristics even without gross body. Opposes views of complete dissolution at death.
Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 4.4.2, Prashnopanishad 3.9-10, Katha Upanishad 2.3.8
अग्नि - The role of fire (Agni) in cremation rites and jiva's upward departure
Does cremation fire have spiritual significance in jiva's departure, or is it merely physical disposal of the body?
Cremation fire is purely material, serving only body disposal with no connection to jiva's spiritual journey.

According to Dvaita: Cremation fire facilitates jiva's proper departure. Madhva: (1) Fire (Agni) has presiding deity who assists departing jiva under Vishnu's direction, (2) Proper cremation rites (antyeshti sanskara) help jiva separate cleanly from gross body—fire purifies connection between gross and subtle bodies, (3) For those on devayana path (to Vaikuntha), Agni is first stage: 'they reach Agni'—the deity Agni, not just physical fire, (4) Rites performed during cremation benefit departed jiva by invoking divine assistance for journey and fulfilling dharmic obligations of living, (5) However, actual destination determined by karma and knowledge, not cremation itself—fire is aid, not cause of liberation or good rebirth. Material acts have spiritual dimensions when performed with proper understanding and devotion. All rituals ultimately serve Vishnu's order.
Dvaita: Madhva validates Vedic rituals as meaningful aids in soul's journey while maintaining that ultimate causation lies in karma and Vishnu's grace, not ritual mechanics alone.
Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 6.2.9-16, Chandogya Upanishad 5.10.1, Katha Upanishad 1.1.19
प्रथमश्रवण - Whether first hearing of Brahma-vidya produces immediate liberation or repeated study is needed
Does one hearing of Brahman-knowledge produce immediate liberation, or are repeated study and meditation necessary?
Single hearing of mahavakyas like 'Tat Tvam Asi' produces instant liberation for qualified aspirants. Repetition is unnecessary.

According to Dvaita: Liberation requires repeated study, meditation, and lifelong devotion to Vishnu, not mere single hearing. Madhva: (1) Knowledge of Vishnu's supremacy must become firm (dridha jnana) through repeated śravaṇa (hearing), manana (reflection), nididhyasana (meditation), (2) Even qualified aspirant needs continued practice (abhyasa) to deepen understanding and devotion—one hearing creates initial understanding, not complete realization, (3) Liberation (moksha) comes only through Vishnu's grace combined with knowledge, devotion, and virtuous life—not mechanical result of hearing words, (4) Scripture's repeated emphasis on 'knowing Vishnu,' 'meditating on Vishnu,' 'worshipping Vishnu' indicates ongoing practice, not one-time event, (5) Madhva's bhakti emphasis: Liberation is through loving devotion to Vishnu developed over lifetime, not intellectual grasp from single hearing. The path is progressive development of God-realization through sustained spiritual discipline under guru's guidance, culminating in Vishnu's grace at death.
Dvaita distinctive: Opposes Advaita's theory of instant liberation through mahavakya realization. Madhva emphasizes gradual deepening of Vishnu-bhakti as true path to moksha.
Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 4.4.21-22, Mundaka Upanishad 3.2.3, Bhagavad Gita 18.55
अश्रुतत्व - Whether knowledge not heard from scripture can lead to liberation
Can knowledge gained through reasoning alone, without scriptural instruction, lead to liberation?
Pure reasoning and logic can reveal Brahman truth independent of scripture.

According to Dvaita: Liberation requires knowledge from authentic scripture (Shruti), not mere reasoning. Madhva: (1) Brahman's nature transcends sense perception and inference—only revealed scripture can teach it authoritatively, (2) Reasoning must be guided by scriptural revelation to avoid error—independent speculation leads to conflicting conclusions, (3) Even great sages require Vedic instruction—Narada approached Sanatkumara, Nachiketa approached Yama, demonstrating necessity of authoritative teaching, (4) Madhva emphasizes guru-parampara (lineage of teachers) transmitting authentic Vishnu-bhakti knowledge from Vedas through Mahabharata and Puranas, (5) Liberation requires correct knowledge of Vishnu's supremacy, jiva's dependence, and eternal distinction—only scripture reveals these truths accurately. Unguided reason produces philosophical errors like Sankhya's atheism, Buddhist nihilism, Advaita's illusionism.
Dvaita: Madhva's epistemology places Shruti as supreme authority. Reason serves scripture, never supersedes it. This guards against speculative philosophy detached from revelation.
Katha Upanishad 1.2.7-9, Mundaka Upanishad 1.2.12-13, Bhagavad Gita 4.34
भाक्त - Whether devotion (bhakti) is essential for liberation or knowledge alone suffices
Is devotion to Vishnu necessary for moksha, or does mere intellectual knowledge of Brahman suffice?
Knowledge (jnana) alone liberates. Devotion is optional emotional expression, not essential requirement.

According to Dvaita: Madhva establishes bhakti (devotion to Vishnu) as absolutely essential for liberation—knowledge without devotion cannot grant moksha. His teaching: (1) Liberation comes only through Vishnu's grace (prasada), which is obtained through loving devotion, not mere intellectual understanding, (2) Knowledge of Vishnu's supremacy must transform into love and surrender—dry intellectual comprehension without devotional relationship is insufficient, (3) Bhakti includes: constant remembrance of Vishnu (smarana), love (prema), dedication of all actions (arpana), and complete dependence (sharanagati), (4) The sequence is: knowledge of Vishnu's greatness → wonder and appreciation → love → devotion → grace → liberation, (5) Even in Vaikuntha, liberated souls eternally engage in blissful loving service to Vishnu—bhakti is not just means but also the eternal nature of mukti. Madhva's distinctive position: bhakti is both sadhana (means) and sadhya (goal)—the path and the destination.

Dvaita's bhakti emphasis: This distinguishes Madhva from Advaita where jnana alone suffices. For Madhva, relationship with Vishnu through devotion is central to spiritual life and moksha. Liberation is personal and devotional, not impersonal absorption. Bhakti transforms knowledge from concept to living reality.
Mundaka Upanishad 3.2.3, Katha Upanishad 1.2.23, Bhagavad Gita 18.55, 18.65-66
कृतात्यय - Whether knowledge destroys accumulated karma (sanchita) or only prevents future bondage
Does Brahma-vidya destroy all past accumulated karma (sanchita karma), or does karma continue to fructify even after knowledge arises?
Knowledge of Brahman immediately destroys all accumulated karma. The knower becomes instantly liberated (sadyo-mukti).

According to Dvaita: Madhva teaches that true knowledge of Vishnu destroys sanchita karma (accumulated from past births) and prevents agami karma (future accumulation), but prarabdha karma (already begun to fructify in this life) must be exhausted through experience. His teaching: (1) Sanchita karma is burnt by Vishnu-jnana combined with His grace—past karmic deposits lose binding power, (2) Prarabdha karma continues because the body exists to exhaust it—this explains why even jnanis experience pleasure and pain, (3) New karma (agami) does not bind the knower who acts with Vishnu-arpana bhava (offering all to Vishnu), (4) Complete liberation (videha-mukti) occurs only after death when prarabdha exhausts and the body falls, (5) Living liberation (jivanmukti in Advaita sense of identity with Brahman) is impossible—jiva remains eternally distinct. Knowledge destroys ignorance and binding karma, but embodied existence continues until prarabdha concludes.

Dvaita vs Advaita: Madhva rejects instant disembodied liberation. Even the knower must exhaust prarabdha karma. This explains continued suffering of wise people and rejects the Advaitic jivanmukta (liberated while living) as one who realizes identity with Brahman. For Madhva, no jiva ever becomes Brahman—eternal distinction remains.
Chandogya Upanishad 6.14.2, Bhagavad Gita 4.37, 18.66
यथेत - Whether knowers of all levels attain the same moksha or different levels exist
Do all liberated souls experience identical moksha, or are there gradations in liberation based on knowledge and devotion levels?
Mukti is uniform—all who attain liberation merge into Brahman and experience identical bliss. No distinctions remain.

According to Dvaita: Madhva's distinctive doctrine of taratamya (hierarchical gradation) extends even to mukti. His teaching: (1) Mukti is not uniform—liberated souls experience Vishnu's bliss according to their intrinsic capacity (svarupa-yogyata), (2) Even in Vaikuntha, the principle of taratamya operates: Lakshmi is supreme among jivas, then Vayu (Mukhya Prana), then other deities, sages, and devotees in descending order, (3) All muktas have direct vision (aparoksha-jnana) of Vishnu and eternal bliss, but intensity and comprehension vary according to innate capacity, (4) This gradation is eternal and based on jiva's intrinsic nature—not earned or changeable—it reflects Vishnu's will in creating diversity, (5) No jiva ever becomes equal to Vishnu or to Lakshmi—eternal distinctions and hierarchy persist in moksha. Liberation means freedom from suffering and attainment of bliss appropriate to one's nature, not uniformity or identity with Vishnu.

Dvaita's unique taratamya: This is Madhva's most distinctive doctrine. Even in liberation, jivas maintain unique individual capacity and experience. This opposes both Advaita (all become identical Brahman) and some Vaishnava schools (all muktas are equal). Madhva's moksha preserves eternal diversity and personality.
Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 4.4.6, Bhagavad Gita 7.18, Vishnu Purana
चरण - Whether students of different Vedic shakhas (branches) must perform vidyas (meditations) taught only in their own shakha or can adopt from others
Are vidyas taught in one Vedic shakha (branch) applicable to students of other shakhas, or must each follow only their own tradition?
Each shakha's students must follow only their own prescribed vidyas. Mixing traditions violates guru-parampara and Vedic injunctions.

According to Dvaita: Madhva teaches that fundamental vidyas about Vishnu's supremacy are universal and should be adopted by all students regardless of shakha, while specific ritual details may vary by tradition. His position: (1) All Vedic shakhas ultimately teach the same Vishnu-tattva (truth about Vishnu)—the object of meditation is one Supreme Vishnu, not different entities, (2) Core vidyas like Dahara Vidya, Sandilya Vidya, and Vaisvanara Vidya reveal Vishnu's nature and are universally applicable, (3) Students should learn all authentic vidyas that reveal Vishnu's greatness, supplementing their shakha's teaching with others' valid meditations, (4) Ritual procedures (karma-kanda) may differ by shakha, but jnana-kanda teaching is universal truth, (5) However, one must remain under proper guru guidance and not independently mix practices—the guru determines which vidyas suit the student. Unity in object (Vishnu) permits diversity in meditation approaches.

Dvaita universalism within tradition: Madhva balances sectarian tradition with universal truth. All Vedas teach Vishnu, so their vidyas are mutually compatible in essence. This allows Madhva's followers to draw from all Vedic sources while maintaining guru-parampara integrity.
Chandogya Upanishad various vidyas, Taittiriya Upanishad, Brahma Sutra 3.3.11
अनिष्टादिकार्य - Whether negative results (anishta) mentioned in Upanishads apply to Brahma-vidya or only to its neglect
Do Upanishadic passages threatening harm apply to those who know Brahman incorrectly, or to those who neglect Brahma-vidya entirely?
Negative results apply to incorrect knowledge—those who meditate wrongly on Brahman suffer punishment.

According to Dvaita: Madhva clarifies that negative results (suffering, bondage, hell) apply to those who willfully neglect or reject Vishnu's supremacy, not to sincere seekers with incomplete understanding. His teaching: (1) Those who deny Vishnu's supremacy (asuras, atheists) or claim equality with Vishnu face severe consequences—eternal exclusion from mukti and descent into lower realms, (2) Those who worship other entities as supreme while denying Vishnu commit the gravest error (Vishnu-ninda), leading to tamo-yogyata (qualification for darkness), (3) Sincere devotees with incomplete knowledge who accept Vishnu's supremacy but lack full understanding do not suffer these penalties—Vishnu's grace compensates for their limitations, (4) Errors in ritual details or meditation techniques can be corrected and do not cause ultimate harm to sincere seekers, (5) The crucial distinction is intention and basic acceptance of Vishnu-sarvottamatva—those who fundamentally accept Vishnu's supremacy will progress toward mukti. Willful rejection, not innocent error, brings severe consequences.

Dvaita's doctrinal rigor with grace: Madhva is strict about Vishnu-sarvottamatva being essential truth, yet merciful toward sincere seekers. The unforgivable error is denying Vishnu's supreme position, not imperfect practice. This distinguishes eternally liberable jivas from tamo-yogya (qualified for darkness).
Chandogya Upanishad 5.10.8, Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 3.8.10, Bhagavad Gita 16.19-20
सप्त - The seven pranas (vital functions) mentioned in Upanishads and their meditation significance
What are the seven pranas mentioned in Upanishads? Do they refer to seven physiological functions, seven deities, or aspects of Brahman?
The seven pranas are merely physiological vital airs with no spiritual significance beyond bodily function.

According to Dvaita: Madhva interprets the seven pranas as seven manifestations of Vishnu's life-giving power operating at different levels. His teaching: (1) The seven include: the five pranas (prana, apana, vyana, samana, udana), plus mind and intellect—all sustained directly by Vishnu as antaryamin, (2) Each prana has a presiding deity under Vishnu's control—Mukhya Prana (Vayu) chief among them, governing all vital functions on Vishnu's behalf, (3) Meditation on these seven as Vishnu's instruments establishes awareness that all life processes depend entirely on Vishnu's will—no independent vitality exists, (4) The seven gates/openings of the body through which pranas operate are also sanctified by this understanding, (5) Recognizing Vishnu's control over vital functions leads to understanding His complete sovereignty over life and death. This meditation establishes dependence consciousness (paratantra-bodha) essential for bhakti.

Dvaita's comprehensive theism: Even bodily functions become meditation objects revealing Vishnu's all-pervasiveness. Nothing is merely material or mechanical—all processes reflect Vishnu's governing presence. This transforms physiology into theology.
Chandogya Upanishad 5.1.1-15, Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 1.5.3, Prashna Upanishad 3.6-7
तद्व्यापार - Whether actions performed after acquiring Brahma-vidya bind the knower or remain non-binding
Do actions performed by one who knows Brahman continue to produce karma, or does knowledge make all subsequent actions non-binding?
After knowledge arises, all actions cease to bind. The knower can act freely without karmic consequences.

According to Dvaita: Madhva teaches that actions performed with Vishnu-arpana bhava (offering-attitude to Vishnu) after acquiring knowledge do not bind, but actions done with selfish motivation continue to produce karma. His teaching: (1) Knowledge of Vishnu's supremacy transforms action's intention—when all is done as service to Vishnu (nimitta-bhava), ego-based doership dissolves, (2) The knower recognizes Vishnu as the true doer (karta), the jiva as instrument—this understanding prevents binding, (3) However, if the knower acts with desire for personal gain or from ego despite knowledge, karma continues to accumulate—mere intellectual knowledge without devotional transformation is insufficient, (4) True jnani performs all duties as yajna (sacrifice to Vishnu), maintaining ethical conduct not from fear but from love, (5) Renunciation is internal (detachment from fruits) not necessarily external (abandoning all action)—karma-yoga as taught by Krishna. Actions become non-binding when performed with complete Vishnu-surrender, not by mere knowledge alone.

Dvaita's karma-yoga: Madhva synthesizes jnana and karma through bhakti. Knowledge without devotional surrender is incomplete. The liberated person acts in the world but with transformed consciousness—all activity becomes worship. This differs from Advaita where activity indicates incomplete knowledge.
विद्याकर्म - The relationship between knowledge (vidya) and prescribed duties (karma) for spiritual aspirants
Should seekers of Brahma-vidya abandon all karmas, or should they continue performing prescribed duties while pursuing knowledge?
Complete renunciation of all karma is necessary for Brahma-vidya. Rituals belong to lower path and must be abandoned by serious seekers.

According to Dvaita: Madhva strongly advocates continuing nitya-karmas (daily obligatory duties) and naimitika-karmas (occasional duties) throughout life, even for advanced seekers. His teaching: (1) Prescribed duties according to one's varna and ashrama purify the mind (chitta-shuddhi) and maintain cosmic order (loka-sangraha), (2) Abandoning ordained duties violates dharma and creates negative karma—even jnanis must fulfill dharmic obligations, (3) Kamya-karmas (desire-motivated rituals) alone should be abandoned—they bind through desire, but obligatory duties performed as Vishnu-seva do not bind, (4) The ideal is karma-yoga: performing all duties as worship of Vishnu without attachment to results, combining action with devotion and knowledge, (5) Monasticism (sannyasa) is a specific ashrama with its own duties, not abandonment of all action—even sannyasis have obligations of study, teaching, and worship. Integration of vidya and karma through bhakti is Madhva's path—not renunciation of duty but transformation of attitude.

Dvaita's integrated path: Madhva rejects extreme renunciation. Dharmic action continues throughout life but is transformed by bhakti. This practical approach makes spiritual life accessible to householders, not requiring world-abandonment. Gita's karma-yoga is central to Madhva's teaching.
Bhagavad Gita 3.5-8, 18.5-9, Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 4.4.22
महातम - The nature of tamas (darkness/ignorance) and the fate of those qualified for it (tamo-yogya)
What is the ultimate fate of those in ignorance? Can all jivas eventually attain liberation, or are some eternally excluded?
All jivas will eventually attain liberation after exhausting karma through cycles of rebirth. None are eternally damned.

According to Dvaita: Madhva's unique and controversial doctrine of tamo-yogyata (qualification for darkness) teaches that jivas are of three eternal categories. His teaching: (1) Nitya-muktas: eternally liberated souls like Lakshmi who never experienced bondage, (2) Mukti-yogyas: jivas qualified for eventual liberation who will attain Vaikuntha after purification through births, devotion, and Vishnu's grace, (3) Tamo-yogyas (or nitya-samsarins): jivas eternally qualified for darkness—including asuras, rakshasas, and those who persistently deny Vishnu's supremacy and commit Vishnu-ninda (blasphemy of Vishnu). These souls after descending through increasingly lower births ultimately enter eternal darkness (andhantamas). (4) This classification is based on jivas' intrinsic nature (svarupa), not earned but reflecting Vishnu's creative will, (5) Scriptures describe eternal hell (naraka) for the wicked, not temporary punishment. This preserves divine justice—willful rejection of Vishnu has eternal consequences.

Dvaita's controversial doctrine: Tamo-yogyata is Madhva's most debated teaching. It preserves scriptural references to eternal damnation and explains persistent evil. Critics argue it contradicts divine compassion; Madhva responds that it reflects both justice and the jiva's inherent nature chosen by Vishnu's inscrutable will. This radically differs from Advaita (all eventually realize Brahman) and most other schools.
Chandogya Upanishad 5.10.8, Katha Upanishad 1.3.14, Bhagavad Gita 16.19-20, Vishnu Purana
तत्स्वाभाव्य - The inherent nature (svabhava) of jivas and whether it can change
Is a jiva's fundamental nature (svarupa) changeable through effort and grace, or is it eternally fixed?
All jivas have identical potential and can change their nature through spiritual practice. Inherent nature is not fixed.

According to Dvaita: Madhva teaches that each jiva has an eternal, unique, unchangeable essential nature (svarupa-svabhava) determined by Vishnu. His teaching: (1) Jivas are eternally distinct not only from Vishnu but from each other—no two jivas are identical even in essence, (2) The intrinsic capacity (yogyata) for spiritual realization varies eternally among jivas—this is the basis of taratamya (hierarchy), (3) Three eternal categories exist: nitya-muktas, mukti-yogyas, and tamo-yogyas—a jiva cannot change categories as this is svabhava (essential nature), (4) However, within one's category, progress is possible—mukti-yogyas advance toward liberation through effort and grace, experiencing varying degrees of spiritual realization, (5) This svabhava is not karma-based but reflects Vishnu's sovereign creative choice—it explains diversity in spiritual aptitude despite similar opportunities. While spiritual state (avastha) can change, fundamental nature (svabhava) is eternal.

Dvaita's predestination aspect: This teaching resembles theological predestination but differs—it's not arbitrary divine whim but recognition of inherent diversity Vishnu creates. Madhva sees this as preserving both divine sovereignty and eternal individual uniqueness. Critics argue it contradicts free will; Madhva responds that free will operates within svabhava parameters.
Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 4.4.5, Bhagavad Gita 7.13-14, 18.40-41
नातिचिरेण - How quickly liberation can be attained after acquiring true knowledge
Does liberation occur immediately upon knowledge, or is there a delay? What determines the timing?
Liberation is instantaneous upon realization of Brahman-identity. The knower is immediately free.

According to Dvaita: Madhva teaches that liberation occurs 'not after a long time' (naaticharena) but only after death when prarabdha karma exhausts. His teaching: (1) Videha-mukti (disembodied liberation): Liberation happens only after the physical body falls—no embodied liberation (jivanmukti in Advaita sense) is possible, (2) After acquiring firm Vishnu-bhakti and knowledge, the devotee's remaining life exhausts prarabdha karma, then at death Vishnu's grace grants mukti, (3) The duration depends on prarabdha's extent—for some it's the same life, for others a few more births while maintaining devotion and knowledge, (4) 'Not after long time' means liberation is certain and relatively swift for sincere devotees, not delayed indefinitely across countless births, (5) In death, the mukti-yogya jiva travels via devayana (path of light) to Vaikuntha, never to return. The timing is in Vishnu's hands but assured for true bhaktas.

Dvaita realism about liberation: Madhva rejects instant liberation while ensuring it's not impossibly distant. Videha-mukti after prarabdha exhaustion is realistic and aligns with continued experience of embodied devotees. This balances scriptural promises of liberation with observable reality of saints' suffering.
Chandogya Upanishad 6.14.2, Mundaka Upanishad 3.2.9, Bhagavad Gita 8.5-6
अन्या - Whether the departing soul travels to a different place (Vaikuntha) or merges into Brahman
Does the liberated jiva travel to Vishnu's abode (Vaikuntha) and dwell there eternally, or does it merge into Brahman losing individuality?
Liberation means merging into Brahman. The jiva loses individual existence, like rivers merging into ocean. No separate abode exists.

According to Dvaita: Madhva emphatically teaches that liberated jivas travel to Vaikuntha (Vishnu's supreme abode) and eternally dwell there maintaining complete individuality and personality. His teaching: (1) Vaikuntha is a real, transcendent realm beyond material universe—not metaphorical but actual divine abode where Vishnu dwells in supreme form, (2) Liberated jivas via devayana path reach Vaikuntha and experience eternal bliss serving Vishnu in loving relationship—no merger or loss of identity occurs, (3) Each mukta maintains unique personality, consciousness, and capacity—experiencing Vishnu's presence according to individual svarupa, (4) The relationship is eternal—jiva as servant, Vishnu as master; jiva as devotee, Vishnu as beloved; diversity in unity, not uniformity, (5) Scriptural references to 'becoming Brahman' mean attaining Brahman-qualities (bliss, knowledge) not identity—'sayujya' means intimate association, not merger. Mukti is personal, relational, and eternally individual.

Dvaita's personalism: This is core Dvaita doctrine opposing Advaita's merger concept. For Madhva, liberation is attaining supreme relationship with Vishnu, not losing existence. Vaikuntha is real heaven, not symbolic. Individual personality is eternal and precious, never dissolved.
Chandogya Upanishad 8.12.3, Mundaka Upanishad 3.2.8-9, Bhagavad Gita 8.21, 15.6
रेतस् - The jiva's entry into a new body through the process of conception and birth
How does the transmigrating jiva enter a new body? At what stage of conception does jiva enter?
Jiva enters only at birth or after formation of the fetus. Before that, only biological processes occur.

According to Dvaita: Madhva teaches that the jiva clothed in subtle body enters at conception, joining with the seed (retas) at the moment of fertilization. His teaching: (1) The jiva accompanied by Vishnu as antaryamin and carrying subtle body enters the womb at conception, not later, (2) The jiva's karma determines the specific parents, family, body type, and circumstances of birth—Vishnu directs the jiva to appropriate womb matching karmic desert, (3) The developing embryo is animated from conception—the jiva experiences the womb state though with limited consciousness, (4) Birth is painful because of jiva's prior karma and the traumatic transition, yet Vishnu's presence as inner controller sustains the jiva throughout, (5) The connection of jiva to particular body is karma-based but Vishnu-directed—no randomness exists in birth circumstances. This explains varying fortunes of birth—all results from past karma and Vishnu's just governance.

Dvaita embryology: Madhva's teaching validates traditional view that life begins at conception. The jiva's presence from conception gives sanctity to all stages of development. Karma explains birth inequality without injustice—Vishnu ensures perfect justice in assigning births.
Aitareya Upanishad 1.1-3, Chandogya Upanishad 5.10.6-7, Bhagavad Gita 13.21
योनि - The different types of bodies (yonis) jivas can inhabit—gods, humans, animals, plants
Can jivas transmigrate into all types of bodies including animals and plants, or is rebirth limited to human and divine forms?
Jivas only take human or divine births. Animal and plant bodies lack the capacity for housing conscious jivas.

According to Dvaita: Madhva affirms that jivas can inhabit all types of bodies—divine, human, animal, and even plant—according to karma. His teaching: (1) There are 84 lakh (8.4 million) species/yonis mentioned in scriptures—jivas cycle through these based on karma accumulated, (2) Movement is both upward and downward: good karma elevates to human or divine births; bad karma degrades to animal, insect, or even plant existence, (3) Even in lower births, the jiva retains its essential consciousness and experiences karma-phala, though with severely limited expression and awareness, (4) Human birth is precious (durlabha manushya janma) because only humans can perform karma-yoga and bhakti leading to moksha—animal forms lack this capacity, (5) Vishnu as antaryamin is present in all bodies controlling and witnessing—even a plant has Vishnu within, though jiva's expression is minimal. The cycle continues until mukti-yogya jivas attain human birth, develop devotion, and gain Vishnu's grace.

Dvaita cosmology: Madhva's acceptance of transmigration through all life forms validates traditional Hindu cosmology and explains compassion toward all creatures. It emphasizes human birth's precious opportunity for spiritual advancement, motivating ethical living and devotion.
Chandogya Upanishad 5.10.7-8, Bhagavad Gita 8.3, 16.19-20, Puranas
सन्ध्या - Whether meditations (vidyas) taught in different Upanishadic contexts should be combined or kept separate
When similar meditations on Brahman are taught in different Upanishads, should they be combined into one comprehensive meditation, or practiced separately?
Each vidya is independent. Meditations taught in different contexts should not be mixed but practiced as taught in each respective Upanishad.

According to Dvaita: Madhva teaches that vidyas about the same object (Vishnu) with similar attributes should be combined (samuchaya) into one comprehensive meditation, while vidyas about different aspects or with contradictory features should be kept separate. His teaching: (1) When multiple Upanishads describe Vishnu with complementary attributes, the meditator should combine all features into one integrated vision of Vishnu, (2) The principle of similarity (sadrishya) determines combination—if the object, attributes, and purpose align, vidyas merge, (3) Different vidyas like Dahara, Sandilya, and Panchagni serve different purposes and remain distinct practices, (4) Combination enriches meditation—learning Vishnu's qualities from all sources deepens devotion and understanding, (5) However, the guru determines which vidyas suit individual students—not all combinations are appropriate for everyone. The goal is comprehensive knowledge of Vishnu leading to complete bhakti.

Dvaita integration: Madhva's approach allows drawing from all Vedic sources to build complete understanding of Vishnu while respecting distinct meditation traditions. This balances comprehensiveness with systematic practice under guru guidance.
Chandogya Upanishad various vidyas, Brihadaranyaka Upanishad, Brahma Sutra 3.3
पराभिध्यान - Whether meditation should focus on the Supreme (Para) Vishnu or on qualified aspects
Should meditation be directed toward Vishnu's supreme transcendent form (Para) or toward His immanent manifestations and qualified attributes?
Meditation on saguna (qualified) Brahman with attributes is sufficient. The attributeless supreme is too abstract for human mind.

According to Dvaita: Madhva teaches that meditation should ultimately be on Para Vishnu (the Supreme) while utilizing qualified forms and attributes as aids. His teaching: (1) Para Vishnu—the supreme transcendent form in Vaikuntha—is the ultimate object of meditation, possessing infinite auspicious qualities (ananta kalyana gunas), (2) Meditation progresses through stages: begin with Vishnu's accessible forms (avataras, murti), then His cosmic manifestations, finally His supreme Para form, (3) Attributes and forms are real, not illusions—they reveal Vishnu's actual nature, making Him accessible to devotees at various levels, (4) The meditator should focus on Vishnu's supremacy (sarvottamatva), His complete independence (svatantrata), and His controller-ship of all (sarvantaryamitva), (5) Ultimately, all meditation aims at developing firm devotion (dridha-bhakti) to Para Vishnu leading to His grace. Forms and attributes are stepping stones to intimate relationship with the Supreme Person.

Dvaita theism: Madhva rejects formless meditation as inadequate. Vishnu is supremely personal with infinite qualities. Meditation is relational communion with the Supreme Person, not dissolution into attributeless void. This distinguishes Dvaita from Advaita's nirguna meditation.
Mundaka Upanishad 3.2.3, Bhagavad Gita 12.5, Vishnu Purana
देहयोग - Whether meditations requiring bodily postures and conditions are essential or optional
Are specific bodily postures, locations, and times essential for meditation on Brahman, or is meditation purely mental and independent of physical conditions?
Meditation is purely mental. Physical conditions like posture, place, and time are irrelevant to spiritual practice.

According to Dvaita: Madhva teaches that while meditation is primarily mental, appropriate bodily discipline and conditions significantly aid spiritual practice. His teaching: (1) Proper sitting posture (asana) steadies the body, which calms the mind—physical stillness supports mental focus, (2) Sacred places (tirtha, temple, solitude) have spiritual vibrations that facilitate meditation—Vishnu's presence is more manifest in consecrated spaces, (3) Auspicious times (brahma-muhurta, sandhya) when sattvic quality dominates make meditation easier and more fruitful, (4) Ritual purity (saucha), proper diet, and ethical conduct create conducive conditions for devotional practice, (5) However, true bhakti transcends all conditions—the advanced devotee can meditate on Vishnu anywhere, anytime. Physical disciplines are aids for most seekers, not absolute requirements for Vishnu's grace. The embodied state requires acknowledging mind-body connection while striving for mental mastery.

Dvaita practical approach: Madhva balances idealism with realism. For most practitioners, physical conditions matter. This validates traditional yoga practices while maintaining that devotion's essence is internal relationship with Vishnu.
Bhagavad Gita 6.11-14, Chandogya Upanishad 8.1, Yoga Sutras
तदभाव - Whether absence of desire and worldly attachments is necessary for meditation
Is complete renunciation of all desires and worldly engagement required for Brahma-vidya, or can meditation be practiced while fulfilling worldly duties?
Total renunciation (sannyasa) is mandatory. One must abandon all desires, possessions, and relationships to pursue Brahman knowledge.

According to Dvaita: Madhva teaches that detachment (vairagya) from selfish desires is essential, but external renunciation is not mandatory for all seekers. His teaching: (1) Internal renunciation—freedom from desire for fruits (nishkama karma)—is necessary; external abandonment is optional and suited only for some, (2) Desires for sensory pleasure (kama), wealth (artha), and ego-gratification must be transcended, but desire for Vishnu (Vishnu-kama) should increase, (3) The householder practicing karma-yoga with Vishnu-arpana bhava can attain moksha—monasticism is one path, not the only path, (4) What must be absent is: attachment to results, sense of doership, and obstacles to devotion. Duties themselves don't bind when performed as worship, (5) The key is transformation of desire—from self-centered to Vishnu-centered—not suppression or elimination. Passionate devotion to Vishnu is the highest state.

Dvaita accessibility: Madhva makes liberation accessible to householders by emphasizing internal transformation over external renunciation. Desire directed toward Vishnu is spiritually valuable, not an obstacle. This validates grihastha dharma as a complete spiritual path.
Bhagavad Gita 3.19, 5.12, 18.6-9, Brihadaranyaka Upanishad 3.5.1
प्रभोध - Whether constant remembrance (smarana) of Vishnu is necessary or occasional meditation suffices
Should the meditator maintain continuous awareness of Brahman throughout daily activities, or is periodic formal meditation sufficient?
Formal meditation sessions at fixed times are sufficient. Constant remembrance is impossible for those engaged in worldly activities.

According to Dvaita: Madhva strongly emphasizes continuous remembrance (akhanda-smarana) of Vishnu as the ideal while acknowledging that capacity varies. His teaching: (1) The highest practice is unbroken awareness of Vishnu (satatam kirtayanto mam)—the advanced devotee maintains Vishnu-consciousness throughout all activities, (2) For most seekers, the practice combines: regular formal meditation sessions (morning, evening) with frequent brief remembrance during daily activities, (3) Every action should be performed with awareness that Vishnu is the witness and controller—this transforms routine work into spiritual practice, (4) The goal is to make Vishnu-smarana as natural as breathing—spontaneous, effortless, constant loving remembrance, (5) Even one-pointed meditation (ekagra chitta) for brief periods is valuable if done with devotion—quality and devotion matter more than duration. Progression: from scheduled meditation → frequent remembrance → constant awareness → absorption in Vishnu.

Dvaita devotion: Madhva's emphasis on continuous remembrance makes spiritual life integrated with daily activities, not separate from them. This is practical bhakti—transforming consciousness through cultivating Vishnu-awareness in all circumstances.
